subject: Re: Acronyms and Abbreviations
msgSnippet: ... Interesting issue. For consonants there s usually an obvious mapping of course but for vowels it is another issue. The example you mention is a great case
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Ron Cameron <ronwcameron@...> wrote:
>
>how does one handle acronyms and/or abbreviations in QS?
>

Interesting issue. For consonants there's usually an obvious mapping
of course but for vowels it is another issue.
The example you mention is a great case in point; which letter is used
for the "A"s in NASA?

If "nasa" is being treated as through it were a word in itself, the
way people actually utter "nasa" would be Nun+At+See+Utter. Two
differnt letters are used to represent the two "A"s

More rational is that the QS abbreviation is of those words written
out fully in QS. But this too leads quickly to grief: the "A"s would
Eight and At (national AEronautics and space Administration). And the
acronym would be pronounced NaySah contrary to actual current usage.
